comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: The "chap" checking his watch is the Station Master and is making sure the train departs on time. The "first" and "second" porters have completed their tasks but also await the departure. The railways were very formal in those days with military style organisation and job progression was often by way of "dead men's shoes".

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/38401430@N06] Sorry about the "chap", but I wasn't 100% sure that he was the Station Master and not just a punctilious passenger. Have changed it now...

First porter with moustache and second porter leaning on the trolley?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Station Masters always wore a bowler - it denoted rank and authority - I agree about the porters as well. 

If you ever get a chance have a look at the Irish Railway Records Society Library & Archive in Dublin. The chances are they could tell you everything about this photo including who filled the engine with coal on that day!

Athboy railway station was the terminus of a branch line which diverged from the Dublin to Navan line at Kilmessan Junction and served the village of Athboy in County Meath.

Opened by the Dublin & Meath Railway, the station was absorbed by the Midland Great Western Railway, and so joined the Great Southern Railways.

The station was then nationalised, passing on to Coras Iompair Éireann as a result of the Transport Act 1944 which took effect from 1 January 1945. 

The Station House dates from 1870. The first trains commenced running from January 1865 which were exclusively cattle trains, the passenger services began by the end of February. The service continued until 1963 when the station closed because popularity of road travel. The role of the railway was central to the development of Athboy particularly relation to the cattle trade where large cattle fairs were held at the Fair Green located beside the station.

comment.author: 48236157@N02
comment._content: That train could be the train featured so prominently in the John Ford movie "The Quiet Man"!

comment.author: 38401430@N06
comment._content: Except the movie was made 150km away at Ballyglunin Station (which was re-named Castletown for the movie) not Athboy. The train in "The Quiet Man" was in CIE livery including the flying snail which wasn't introduced by CIE until 1944.
